title: Component react creators
content:
#

As of now we have only one utility, we plan to create more, of course, in the
following weeks.

This utility is the react component creators


What does it do?#

These utilities are actually react component factories for what some libraries
like MUI and Mantine know as Polymorphic Components and also to create
components that extract some props and use them to resolve the className. There
is a reason we are creating this; we have some ideas in mind following the
article we published in medium to create some optimizations in build/compile
time.

In short, this means you can create a Button that can render not only as a
button but as any other React ElementType.

Also you are going to be able to create a className resolver function that
extracts from your props what info is needed to create a className according to,
for instance, some variants of your component, and separate them from the real
props of the component.

I almost forgot to mention that it is typesafe, so your IDE is going to
autocomplete the needed props.

> ⚠️ WARNING: This library is only compatible with React 19. It will not work
> with earlier versions of React due to dependency on new features and APIs
> introduced in React 19.


Installation#


Usage#


Creating a styled component#

This is a factory of a polymorphic component that also accepts variant props for
your custom className resolver



The extractStyleProps is a needed function to separate what props are real props
of your component (componentOwnProps) and what props are going to be used to
resolve the className (styleProps).

The classNameResolver will only get what you defined in extractStyleProps as
styleProps and you may use that to form your final className to get the correct
styles.

Sometimes you would want not to modify the className but the style prop, this is
to apply change control via css vars; for those cases we provide a styleResolver
function.





In any case, you can use the Button component like this:




Example with tailwindVariants and Rambda#



Then you can use your shiny button like this



Why would I want a button that is a link? Well, because sometimes you need the
styles of a button in an anchor tag.


Creating a only polymorphic component#

But if you do not want to create a custom className resolver and only need a
polymorphic component you can use createReactMetaComponent


Creating a component that extracts some props to create the className#

But this time it is not a polymorphic component, you can use
createComponentWithStyleProps and the component is not going to have an as prop.



This component is always going to be a button.


Final words#

Obviously you may use directly a classname resolver of your liking directly in
any component directly in the code like this (suppose we were using
tailwindVariants):



And it is really good, but we wanted to give some structure to react components
to make them have all your variants by props.

If you read the article about our ideas that came from our adventures in the
place where we study, you may know we are planning on using a compiler to make
some optimizations at build time.

And since react is something that is going to be in our projects, we wanted to
make the first step in this direction.

title: Tailwind Manifest Creators
content:
#


Introduction#

The @dyesthetics-lab/tailwind-manifest-creators package creates manifest files
containing all Tailwind CSS class variants used in your project. A manifest file
is a collection of all the Tailwind classes that your application might use,
which are extracted from your configuration files. This manifest enables
Tailwind to efficiently process only the classes your application actually
needs, improving build performance and reducing CSS bundle size.

WARNING

This package is specifically designed to work with Tailwind CSS v4, which
introduced the @source directive for improved class extraction.


Installation#


Usage#


Manifest Creator#

The package exports a createManifest function that generates a manifest file
containing all Tailwind class variants that match a specified glob pattern.

To implement this in your build process, create a pre-build script file (e.g.,
pre-build.ts):



The globPath parameter specifies which files to scan for Tailwind class
definitions. In this example, we're searching for all files with the
.tailwindConfig.json extension.


Configuration Files#

Your project should contain one or more configuration files matching the
specified glob pattern. These files define the Tailwind variants your components
use.

Example tailwindConfig.json:



INFO

Note that the responsiveVariants option in your configuration controls whether
responsive variants are generated. When set to true, the manifest will include
responsive variants (like sm:, md:, lg:) for your classes. The tool does not
automatically create responsive variants - it generates them based on your
configuration.


Integrating with Your Build Process#

Configure the pre-build script in your package.json:



When you run your build process, the pre-build script will execute first,
creating a global.tailwind.manifest file in node_modules/.tailwind-manifests/.
This manifest will contain all Tailwind classes found in your configuration
files, including responsive variants if specified.
